I enjoyed this class. It provides a comprehensive understanding of basic ideas in macroeconomics and both Professor Tsyvinski and Dr. Hawkins (the course director) are great. The lectures are engaging and the course is extremely well run. My advice to anyone taking this course would be to make sure to use Piazza because there is a lot there that really helps. Also, the lecture slides that are posted on Canvas are very thorough and are a great resource. The class is less math-intensive than micro. One thing that is slightly annoying is the strict grading curve implemented by the econ department, but on the whole I thought it was an engaging and worthwhile course.

I think this class teaches you a lot about macroeconomic theory but also just about current economic affairs around the world. There's definitely a huge focus on current facts and data -- and a lot of class is spent talking about them, but Professor Tsyvinski connects them to macroeconomic theory in a interesting way.

New insight into economic infrastructures and fundamental macroeconomic models. New awareness of the general state of the global economy and specific countries. Awareness of the key terms and ideas of macroeconomics that I will come across in daily life, and some models to apply to other fields.

This course is extremely well-organized, much more so than ECON 115, Introductory Microeconomics. William Hawkins and the TFs spent a lot of time making sure that the review sessions were taught well and helpful, that we knew what topics were going to be covered on the exam, and that Piazza was always available for quick answers to questions about the problem sets. They also sought student feedback halfway through the term, something that not a lot of large lecture courses do. The topics are also clear cut and easy to understand, Tsyvinski is also an engaging lecturer. 

The weakness of this course is that Tsyvinski does lecture a bit quickly. It's difficult to keep up with note-taking at times because he moves quickly through slides, so I spent a lot of time catching up by looking at slides on my phone as he lectured.

this course was not at all well organized. In lecture, we do not cover any actual problems and examples of the material, rather, the teacher focuses on telling us irrelevant fun facts to jockey favor among students and on very hypothetical, far removed definitions. I honestly felt like i was learning the material relevant to exams in section. They need to make the lecture more applied. Moreover, the course is set up, so that people in lecture will always be the bottom of the curve that props up the seminar people. We have the same curve, yet they learn more, are exposed to the material more, and have more actual practice problems. Lastly, the problem sets are so far removed from the material we learn in class that they are ridiculously trying.
The online quizzes were great.  The lectures were quite boring.

strength: comprehensible slides
weakness: lecture was not engaging/interesting
perfect ratio of econ: jokes. No changes.
lectures are meh but sections are great
It's a big lecture class not much you can do to improve it.

The grading system is awful; a student could receive an 85%, but that wouldn't qualify for a B but still be a B-, which seems to take away from the hard work they put into the class, they need to improve this.

The course has a a good standing because the topics that it covers are engaging and relatable. This is a strength of the course in itself. In addition to that, the course does well in discussing topics more in detail in section so that the students have a complete understanding of what is being taught.
One of the weaknesses of this course is that during lecture, there would be a lot of times when the teaching was rushed because we were running out of time. Thus, we would spend a lot of time on small concepts that we would not later use, but the more important concepts were taught in a rushed manner, leading to confusion.
Lectures could be less monotonous. More variation would entice the student body.
The course was a wide overview of the field of macroeconomics. Section was especially helpful because we were able to tangibly grasp the concepts and apply them to problems.

I really enjoyed this course. A strength is the clarity of the expectations held by the teaching staff. Students knew exactly what they would be held accountable for on homework. Additionally, Piazza and TF office hours were ubiquitous, allowing for help at nearly any time. 

The only weakness I can identify is the grade distribution. This course is likely going to be curved down, so I probably would've liked for the exams to be a bit harder so that there would be more leeway.
The course ensured personal engagement with the material through section participation.

The material we cover is interesting and well presented. Also I LOVE Piazza.
Sometimes we go through slides too fast. Also the sections werent always very helpful.

Strengths are lectures and focus on public policy aspect of economics.
Weaknesses are lack of clarity in problem sets and exams.
The material covers the necessary material, but it does so it a very boring way. Yes, I learned the required material, but I was not engaged and honestly somewhat dreaded going to class.
Lecture was good and the class was very well run. My advice would be to perhaps bring more theory and economic models into the course in place of some of the historical information and case examples.

I think the strength of this course is the emphasis on real-world application, because it makes the course more interesting. But I also think this is the weakness -- a lot of times in class, we go over data that is hard to understand, abstract, and we never talk about it again, so it seems somewhat irrelevant.

The content of this course is valuable and interesting; however, I think it could have been structured much better if it went directly off of the intro micro class. While there are a few key new models, many of the topics of macroeconomics are essentially microeconomics set within a more complex, more realistic context, and I think they should have been presented as such. However, there seemed to be an assumption that we would e familiar with the basics of macroeconomic infrastructure, and so very little time was spent defining the new context for the micro concepts we learned last semester. For example, I think it would be valuable to spend time explicitly discussing the definitions of simple things like markets, banks, interest, etc. Instead, this time was spent on details of the global economy. This is valuable information, but should not take so much time to convey at the cost of teaching a true intro class to macro novices.

My TA was extremely helpful and knew the material well and could explain the stuff taught in lectures in section. The lectures were interesting because Aleh always included data and graphs to supplement materials.

The lectures were long and were held in the afternoon and so many students would stop paying attention after a while or could not concentrate throughout.

The course provided a lot of resources to help with study and understanding. Lots of TA office hours and online materials, fast response time on Piazza. The content was interesting. However, the order that the material was taught in could have been much improved. Much of the material in macro is just micro in a new setting. Thus, we should have started by defining the macroeconomic infrastructure (for example, taking the time to explicitly define things like markets, banks, interest, as we did with GDP at the beginning) and then built upon the models we learned in micro. In addition, a lot of time was spent on real-world data. This is interesting and valuable, but not worth the trade-off of clearer definitions/background info for the concepts.

what was taught in lecture was the exact same material as what was in the textbook so didn't really have to go to lecture could just read the textbook and go to section and get the same out of it. Also the econ department curve ended up curving a lot of students down because the exams were too easy
The lectures were really really bad. 1/2 of the class didn't show up to them, and 1/2 of the people who did show up slept through them or didn't pay attention.

Strengths: It was well-structured and well put together. I appreciated that there were no questions about what we needed to know, and I liked how actively committed to Piazza the TFs were. 

Weaknesses: It moved too slowly at times. I wish the class was a bit more theoretical and less example driven (the examples were interesting, but often took up too much time).

This class is, without a doubt, the most well-coordinated class at Yale. Everything is super well organized, from the psets to the exam information to the lectures. Also, lectures were incredible once I learned to understand Prof. Tsyvinski's accent. He's brilliant and always knows how to crack a funny joke and relate the core concepts of intro macro (like comparative advantage) to simpler examples that expand understanding.

This class gives you a basic understanding of a lot of topics that are very applicable to the real world. Problem sets are doable, exams are almost too easy (to the point where a silly mistake screws you over), but it is good knowledge for everyone to have. Sometimes it seems as though there is a large disconnect between lecture and section.
I thought that it was a very well planned course

I liked that the class was very organized and very structured, so there were never any surprises about what would be on the psets or the exams. Dr. Hawkins was very on top of answering piazza questions and sending announcements out about exam topics and times, and grading of assignments was relatively prompt for such a large class.
One of the weaknesses I would say is that the quality of TAs is inconsistent, with some sections being much better than others. Also, there were times when I felt like the questions were not discussed in lecture to the depth that the psets asked for.
I really liked the straight-forward textbook that was tailor-made to the class. The expectations were clear, and I honestly don't think there's much I would change.

PSETs could be more clearly worded
Make midterms out of 100 points; instead of giving "extra credit" for writing name, just dock points off. It's confusing when it's not out of 100 and seems like grade deflation

Also, while the textbook was great because it was much more condensed than a regular one, it was confusing having a lot of math and derivations that werent really pertinent.
Sometimes the material is very broad and it's hard to understand what is required for the course and sometimes it's very specific material. A balance between the two would make this course greater.

I wish that the professors assigned readings and had online reading quizzes because it would be much easier to keep up with the material. I also feel that this class was not intro enough, in that it didn't give basic definitions that I needed, for example what is a bank?. I liked piazza.

The textbook was written by Professor Tsyvinski and Dr. Hawkins, which made it tailored specifically to the class. During Psets, I found myself bouncing back between the slides and the textbook for support, and Piazza as well when I needed it.
well taught!

Comprehensive and used realistic examples. Could be improved with more examples and practice problems, and not all models are realistic which is frustrating.

The main strength of this course, particularly as it compares to Intro Micro, is how immediately relevant the material is to the real world. However, in practice, much of the real-world analysis and examples we went over in lecture felt irrelevant and distracting from the fundamentals we needed to know. Generally, this class could often feel scattered and all-over-the-place, as lecture and lecture notes were not concise or focused. Also, I think exams should be made more difficult in order to increase the spread of scores. As they were, the midterms were very straightforward, but that actually made the curve much worse, since the exam average was extremely high and small deviations in scores corresponded to large changes in letter grade.
I really enjoyed lecture, but I would have appreciated more structure in section.

This class included an abundance of interesting and relevant material.  However, the professors and facilitators of the course could have done a better job linking these different ideas and theories together.

- Pros
    - Liked the pset with articles to contextualize exactly what were learning with real world examples
    - Liked the real world examples
    - Liked the myriad office hours and support
    - Ravi was an amazing TA 
- Cons
    - I think that the policy for 40% A, 50% B, 10% C are an unhealthy means of getting students to engage in the material, and I think it causes undue stress. I suggest that we try to change this to have normal grade cut-offs that aren't based on distributions.

The biggest strength of this course was how well they tied in everything to real world examples; it made the concepts feel much less abstract. I also think the class did a really good job of using Piazza, where all the questions were answered thoroughly and promptly. I think the main way the course could be improved is if there were a stronger textbook / the textbook that the instructors made went at least as in depth as the lectures did; it could be frustrating when you didn't understand a topic in lecture, and then the textbook gave only a cursory overview of the topic.

Prof. Could pace the lecture better by spending less time on easier material and more on harder parts. He tended to spend a lot of time in the beginning of the lecture, and speed through the last chunk of slides.

Lectures were generally interesting, and discussion section was very helpful for filling in the gaps in my understanding and getting a sense of how to approach each weeks problem sets. The head TF (William Hawkins) did a fantastic job of making clear what we did and did not need to know for each exam by putting together a comprehensive list of each topic, idea, and fact that we needed to be familiar with for every lecture. I believe that the strengths of this course are the abundant amount of resources available to students to study the material of this class and to prepare for exams. The instructors provided notes from each lecture, section review, chapter notes, additional questions, office hours, and exam review sessions. The weaknesses of this course are the sections. The questions taught during section didn't always reflect material covered during that week's lectures and the section TA's weren't always able to explain the questions clearly. This could be improved by encouraging attendance to section so more people attend section so the room isn't as silent as it was in my section and to ensure that the section TA's understand the material well and can instruct students about this information.

William Hawkins is the greatest asset to this course. The range in TA quality was shocking - some were very uncomfortable teaching and did not know the material well. From what I can tell, Hawkins was working around the clock answering Piazza questions, organizing people and schedules, and generally knowing his sh**.

Concepts were very innteresting, but the curve was very hard, to the point where students received lower grades from the curve than they got on the tests percentage-wise. Either the tests should be made more difficult, or the curve shohld be made more friendly.

I really appreciated the format of the notes in this course. It was helpful to have complete slides for review. A weakness of this course is that it has an incredibly large class size. A possible improvement would be to make the information in the discussion section more concise.

I think the class is great the way it is. As opposed to many other courses, section time is spent reviewing content covered in class. which I really appreciate.

The class is genuinely an introductory class, every chapter focuses on only the big picture stuff and is an excellent fit for even non econ majors.

Also, some Math was introduced during lectures, but students just had to memorize results without having to prove them like in Microeconomics.

Allow laptops.  I like to take notes electronically for easy future reference and to change slides at my own pace.

I thought that the lectures and problem sets were well designed. I really liked the online quiz portion of the problem sets because I was able to test my comprehension and learn from my mistakes without suffering consequences. I know the course was being restructured, but I wish there had been more practice problems or tests online that were relevant to the current material. For intro micro, there were also office hours in the CTL before a pset was due and that would have also been helpful.

First off, this class was pretty much restructured for this semester, based on a lot of feedback they had received about it in previous semesters. You can tell that the course director, William Hawkins, and Professor Tsyvinski really tried to redo the course so that the content was more applicable to what students need to know about introductory macroeconomics, and it also seems like it was a lot easier than when it was taught in previous semesters. Another strength is that pretty much everything you need to do well in the course is on the Canvas website and Piazza- those two resources are pretty well-organized and I probably wouldnt have survived without Piazza (huge shoutout to Dr. Hawkins for answering basically every question in a really timely manner!). Since the course was pretty different than how it was taught in previous semesters, it was a little confusing to estimate what material you did and didnt need to know for exams based on old exams. However, the homework problem sets and the section practice problems were really good guides to the kinds of things that would be on exams. I would say one weakness is that lecture wasnt really the most helpful for understanding the material.
Fantastically-run course. Would not change a thing. If anything, maybe Learning Catalytics would benefit the overall engagement level in lectures.

Id say a strength was Professor Tsyvinskis organization, as well as very organized sections and piazza boards.

Some weaknesses - way too much material covered in notes that wasnt included in tests and some TFs couldnt properly teach the material.
This course covers a broad range of topics and was effectively organized. We were provided with plenty of resources to do well and the material was engaging.

This course was overall a very good primer on macroeconomics, but I think harder tests would be useful. The curve was extremely competitive, with an A grade being in the mid 90% range. A harder test would give a more reasonable curve.

I would definitely recommend it to someone who has taken micro and wants a full-year, thorough understanding of basic economics. It is great as a social science credit and interesting. The workload is very manageable.
